hints_html:
This is a typical question for integration by parts. Recall the formula

\[\begin{aligned} \int u\,dv = uv - \int v\,du.\end{aligned}\]

What is the easiest choice for u and dv?

Sometimes you have to do integration by parts twice to get to your final answer...

Use integration by parts with \(x\,dx=dv\) and \((\ln(x))^2=u\).

Then use integration by parts a second time with \(x\,dx= dv\) and \(\ln(x) = u\).
hints_latex:
This is a typical question for integration by parts. Recall the formula

\begin{align*}
\int u\,dv = uv - \int v\,du.
\end{align*}

What is the easiest choice for \emph{u} and \emph{dv}?

Sometimes you have to do integration by parts twice to get to your final
answer...
Use integration by parts with $x\,dx=dv$ and $(\ln(x))^2=u$.

Then use integration by parts a second time with $x\,dx= dv$ and
$\ln(x) = u$.
hints_raw:
This is a typical question for integration by parts. Recall the formula

:<math> \int u\,dv = uv - \int v\,du. </math>

What is the easiest choice for ''u'' and ''dv''?

Sometimes you have to do integration by parts twice to get to your final answer...
Use integration by parts with <math> \ x\,dx=dv</math> and <math>\ (\ln(x))^2=u</math>.
Then use integration by parts a second time with
<math>x\,dx= dv\ </math> and <math>\ \ln(x) = u</math>.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
For calculating this integral we use integration by parts two times. We take \(dv=x\,dx\) and \(u = (\ln(x))^2\). Then \(\displaystyle v = \frac{x^2}2\) and \(du = 2\ln(x)\frac1{x}\,dx\) (don’t forget the derivative 1/x of ln(x)).

\[\begin{aligned} \int x(\ln(x))^2dx &= \left[\frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2\right] - \int\frac{x^2}{2}2\ln(x)\frac1xdx\\ &= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \int \underbrace{x}_{dv}\underbrace{\ln(x)}_{u}dx\\ &= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \int\frac{x^2}{2}\frac{1}{x}dx\\ &= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \int\frac{x}{2}dx\\ &= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \frac{x^2}{4} + c\end{aligned}\]

for a constant c.
sols_latex:
For calculating this integral we use integration by parts two times. We
take $dv=x\,dx$ and $u = (\ln(x))^2$. Then
$\displaystyle v = \frac{x^2}2$ and $du = 2\ln(x)\frac1{x}\,dx$ (don't
forget the derivative 1/\emph{x} of \emph{ln(x)}).

\begin{align*}
\int x(\ln(x))^2dx &= \left[\frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2\right] - \int\frac{x^2}{2}2\ln(x)\frac1xdx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \int \underbrace{x}_{dv}\underbrace{\ln(x)}_{u}dx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \int\frac{x^2}{2}\frac{1}{x}dx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \int\frac{x}{2}dx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \frac{x^2}{4} + c
\end{align*}

for a constant \emph{c}.
sols_raw:
For calculating this integral we use integration by parts two times. We take <math>\ dv=x\,dx</math> and <math>\ u = (\ln(x))^2</math>. Then <math>\displaystyle v = \frac{x^2}2</math> and <math> du = 2\ln(x)\frac1{x}\,dx </math> (don't forget the derivative 1/''x'' of ''ln(x)'').

:<math>\begin{align}
\int x(\ln(x))^2dx &= \left[\frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2\right] - \int\frac{x^2}{2}2\ln(x)\frac1xdx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \int \underbrace{x}_{dv}\underbrace{\ln(x)}_{u}dx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \int\frac{x^2}{2}\frac{1}{x}dx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \int\frac{x}{2}dx\\
&= \frac{x^2}{2}(\ln(x))^2 - \frac{x^2}{2}\ln(x) + \frac{x^2}{4} + c\\
\end{align}</math>

for a constant ''c''.
